intro: Calycothrix drummondii, commonly known as the Drummond's ghostflower, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to the arid regions of Southwestern North America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, pale yellow to white flowers that bloom in late spring, often in clusters at the ends of its stems. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
